intro: Chaerophyllum andicola, commonly known as the Andean chervil, is a flowering plant native to the Andes region of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant typically grows in high-altitude grasslands and rocky soils, thriving in cool, temperate climates. It produces small, white or greenish flowers arranged in umbels, which are typical of the Apiaceae family. Due to its unique habitat and limited distribution, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
